page.lettertext:
fol.15r
May it please yo
r
good L. I have imparted as yow willed
her
Hig
es
pleasure to
e
States,
for the calling away
of
S
r
Francis Vere
, to be conferred w
t
a while in some
attempt of great importance, against
e Co
m
on
Enemie. And to
e end
at his departure might
not seme over strange, nor falle prejudicial to
e actions of
e Contrey, I lette them knowe
at her
Hig
es
was desyrous to proceed w
t
their privitie,
and good lyking. Wherto they made no other
scruple, in their answear unto me, but
at they
would consult w
t
e
Councell of Estate
, and
likewise w
t
Co. Maurice
, who had all
e conduction
of
e affaires of
e warres, and doe me therupon,
to witte their answear to her Ma
tie
: wherin it may
be they will signifie, howe muche it doth preju-
dice the State of their affaires, to have any
chief co
m
ander revoked on
e soddaine (for so
ei
do debate it, in their privat co
m
unications)
and will therupon request, to have him p
nt
ly
returned. But I thinke they will not use any
other opposition: and though they should, I
know it will not prevaile w
t
S
r
Francis Vere.
My
L. of Essex
dispatche, w
t
her Ma
ties
l
res
, I
sent [p
nt
ly] for
Duisbourgh,
by a Post of this Contrey,
that was trustie and speedy: that I recken for
his coming within two or three dayes, and that
longer then he taketh his leave of
e State, he
will not stay in this place. Two dayes
past, to goe forward where I ended in my last
to yo
r
L. w
ch
I hope yow have receaved)
M
r
Bar-
nevelt
returned, having bin, as I signified, im-
ployed into
Zeland:
And to tell a long tale as short
as I can, he and other five of
e Province of
Holland,
w
t
fower out of Zeland, were all
at were
deputed to meete in
at session. And though they
came for other businesse, yet that beyng ended,
they were contented all at last, being dealt w
t
all
fol.15v
before, and privately prepared by M
r
Barnevelts dili-
gence, to deliberat there together, about
e mater of
e Ouverture: w
ch
they discussed at
e least for ten or
twelve meetinges. Many dangers and doubtes were
alleaged among them, aswell in regard of inconve-
nience to
e Contrey, w
ch
as divers discoursed, by a
voluntarie dissolution of their Treatie w
t
her Ma
tie
might be mightilie damnified, as of perill to
themselves, and their owne proper welfare, when
as they should be noted, to be movers and advan-
cers of suche kinde of Projectes. The effect
of their objections I have formerly declared, by sundrie
l
res
to yo
r
L. They urged most of all,
e composi-
tion of their State, of suche diversie of factions,
humo
rs
, religions: where so many were desyrous, if
good mater were offered, to sette all a fire:
e weightie
bourden of their imposts, and other kinde of [tallages]
e peoples weerinesse in generall to continue still in
warre:
e faire conditions of Accord presented by
e
Enemie, w
ch
their neighbo
rs
e Germaines, as
e Enemies
pledges would undertake to see perfourmed, [and a]
number of other baites and fraudulent devises, w
ch
would be practised, they thought, by some
at were
corrupted, or ill disposed of themselves, to w
ch
when
this shall be added, of her Ma
ties
intention, to end
her Contract w
t
e Land, whereby they shalbe forced
to surcharge
e Co
m
on people, to raise another regiment,
some were wonderfull afraid, it would turne upside
downe all, and cause a great confusion.
Against those in
e ende other arguments prevailed
to which through orderly persuasion, they thought
e
people would give eare, Her Hig
es
huge expences,
for ten yeares together, her present urgent neede in
her domesticall affaires: her earnest poursuite so long
continued, for some convenient remboursement: her
impression deepely fixed of their unthankefull dispo-
sition: her assistance reduced to very fewe companies
fol.16r
and those not unlykely to be cassed and revoked:
her undoubted inclination not to Leave them un-
assisted, if so be
at heereafter they be driven to
extremitie: and lastly, but in special, her sus-
pected resolution (for they doubt it very highly)
to watche a time of revenge, when they shall
happilie be forced to a large restitution.
Upon this they concluded by pluralitie of voices,
For
e first point,
at it was expedient for them
to intertaine 4000 sodiers of
e English na-
tion, not onely in respect of their valo
r
above
others, but to countenance their warres, as-
well in
e opinion of their owne inhabitants,
as also of other contreys, and of
e Enemie chiefly
as if her Ma
tie
would protect, and support their
cause, unto
e Last. For
e second point,
at
it should be referred to her Hig
es
choise, to
discharge or continew her Auxiliarie forces.
For
e third,
at at
e day of her Hig
es
birth, or
Coronation, or w
at
other tyme she shalbe pleased
they will present a certaine paiment, not yet
agreed upon among them, but, as it seemed,
no lesse, then 20000
li
sterling
every yere
. Fourthly
at
they will not enter into Treatie w
t
e
King of
Spaine
, as they will also require,
at her Ma
tie
would not, without mutual consent.
Fivethly, that
ei will alwayes be readie, as
they are at this p
nt
, to send unto her Ma
tie
suche nombers of shippes, w
t
convenient provi-
sion, as their abilitie will permitte, and her
occasions shall require. Lastly
at heere
after, when they shalbe united, w
t
e rest of
e
Provinces,
or be otherwise established in peace
and tranquillitie,
ei will present unto her
Hig
es
a farre greater portion, then
e former:
wherof, as before, there was neither any su
m
e
fol.16v
in speciall, nor yeres accorded of continuance: but
ei
left it as a mater,
at would be easilie resolved.
This co
m
unication was kept very close among
themselves, w
ch
was had in
e towne of
Zuricksea
e place of their assembly. From thens it was
concluded
at they should presently returne to
their several Colleges, and should cary this con-
ference w
t
verie great secrecie, every man endevo-
ring underhand, and by degrees, to procure
e li-
king of
e best, and
e meetest persons of their Collegues
by imparting to them privatly
e whole plotte, or
a parte onely, and more, or lesse, as
e parties gave
occasion. And
at publikely they should forbeare,
to propose abruptely any Articles, to
e effect a fore
mentioned. Onely this in open place was accoun-
ted sufficient,
at assoone as they returned,
ei should
deliver out of hand
e teno
r
of my last proposition,
and of
e rest of my speeches to
e G
nal
l States, and
therupon demonstrat howe behoofull they had found
it, in their forsaid Consultation, to consider of
some good course, howe to gratifie her Ma
tie
, for
w
ch
it would be very requisit, that some should
be deputed, w
t
competent autoritie, to move the
generall College at
e Hage, to resume
at mater
solemnly, and to advise upon some offer,
at might
both be agreable, to her merites and dignitie, and
not unpleasing heere at home, to their townes, and
to
e multitude. With this determination they
departed to their principals w
t
mutual protestation,
at they would use such diligence, dexteritie and
care to prosecut
e Ouverture, as unles
e Contrey would
oppose too egerly against it, w
ch
they did not suspect,
they would appeere w
t
full Comission, in
e g
nal
l
College w
t
in twentie dayes after: and then labo
r
to per-
suade
e rest of
e Deputies: and by them
e lesser Pro-
vinces: w
ch
doe co
m
only concurre without any contradiction
fol.17r
with Holland and Zeland, as
e principal contri-
butors in all money maters. I will not weerie
yo
r
L. w
t
a tedious recitall of other pettie plottes
betweene me and M
r
Barnevelt, by which
I am to negociat, w
t
some persons in privat,
in an other kinde of forme, for
e better digesting
and ripning of
e mater, w
ch
I finde more and
more full of weightie considerations: and were
e motifes unto me of my last unfortunat returne,
for
at I was desirous, where
e project was so hard
and so quaisie, and so intricat heere, and so
newe in like sort to her Ma
ties
eares, to gaine and
compasse that, in a very short space, by
e meanes
of my presence, w
ch
could not, I was sure, be
maneged, by l
res
, or by messengers, for many
special causes, but very lamely and defectu-
ously, and w
t
a dangerous loose of a great deale
of tyme, and of
e present opportunities.
Wheras yo
r
L. would knowe w
at
opinion is held
of
Count Hohenloes
affection to
e causes of this
Contrey, I doe not finde in conversation,
at
e better
sorte heere doe judge him to be Spanishe, or ill affected
to
e State, but rather on
e other side, so sure and
so sounde in his love to
e Contrey, as they make
no question of it. True it is
at two monethes agoe
there was secret notice given by l
res
out of Germa-
ny, from some persons of qualitie,
at in lykely-
hood had
e meanes to understand it directly,
at
he had uttered some speeches in favo
r
of a Peace,
among
e Princes of Germany: and
at besydes he
had determined to salute
e
Prince of Orenge
,
in his passage towardes
Brussels.
Againe it is
observed
at there is very muche inwardnesse between
e
Duke of Brunswicke
and him; who is undoubtedly
supposed to be a minister of
Spaine.
For the
Duke hath of late resigned unto him divers lordships
fol.17v
heere in Holland, as
e Baronnie of
Liesvelt,
and
e
Seigneurie of Woorden, w
t
dyvers other quillets, which
can not yeeld him so litle, as a thousand markes
by
e yeere. But whether it be so
at all
at proceedeth
of benevolence in
e Duke, or
at
e Count hath dis-
boursed some money, or other wise forgone of his
owne in exchange, I can not come to learne. Once
these are suche ocasions, for which of late he hath
incurred
e suspition of wavering, and of a hollowe
harte unto
e State, in
e judgement of some fewe.
But his continual profession of one religion, w
ch
was
never yet stained w
t
anie report, together w
t
his
long and loial services heere, his marriage of late
w
t
e
Countesse of Buren
, who is zelous in religion,
and exceedingly addicted to all
e causes of this
Contrey; and then
e interest
at he hath in her
States and possessions; w
t
his late newe investure
in
e D. Brunswickes landes, which lye heere in
Holland, are counted special arguments of his
trust and affection. Howbeyt it is certaine,
at
Co. Maurice and he are become incompatible, how-
soever in their meetinges they passe it w
t
a shewe
of a shallowe Civill courtesie. For w
ch
many doe
wishe
at Co. Maurice in his cariages towardes him
would
use him better, or altogether worse, and determine w
t
himself to be fully reconciled (wherof there is no hope)
or devise some quiet meanes to cause him to depart.
For every man doth feare,
at this lingering hart bur-
ning w
t
mixture of disgraces, will drive him in
e end
to some desperat course of dealing, w
ch
by reason of his
alliance and acquaintance w
t
e Germans, is nothing
needefull for this Contrey. The States I doe finde could
be willing enough to give him his passeport, but
ei
owe him at
e least for
e arrierages of his services,
three score thousand poundes Sterling: for recove-
ring wherof, he will be able w
t
his frindes to vexe
fol.18r
and molest every Province in this Contrey. It is
not doubted very muche, but
at he meant to
goe see and visit,
e P. of Orenge, if his voyage
had bin neere him, for
e singular love,
at he
bare to his father (wherof he maketh often
mention) and for his matching w
t
his sister:
which may move him perhaps to treate with
e Prince, to forgoe his Seigneuries in these
Provinces, of which
e Prince is proprietarie, by
e right of his
mother
e Countesse of Buren,
though his sister reape
e revenue. There
hath nothing yet passed, by writing, or by mes-
sage, nor heere is nothing given out of any hu-
mor in
e Prince, as favoring or hating
e people
of this union. But one
at hath bin ever as his
Gouvernor w
t
him, doth nowe, as heeretofore, at
his being in Spaine, both send and write to
e
Countesse of Hohenlo, about
e receaving of his
rentes, wherof
e Countesse hath alwayes, and
doth allowe him a certaine portion.
Of
e nombers remaining of
e English bondes,
that are heere in
e service and pay of
e
States, because they were not mustered, sins
e moneth of No
v
I can come to no certaintie,
but w
at
they were then, yo
r
L. shall see by
e list
heere inclosed, w
t
e places of their garrisons.
In other affaires of these Provinces, and in
e
actions of
e Enemie, there is nothing heere
in talke, but is either uncertaine, or of
at na-
ture, as yo
r
L. will not care to un derstand it.
The Cardinal cometh slowely remayning
yet in
Lorrayne,
or as some men say at
Luxembourgh,
w
t
6000 foote, and 1200 horse.
and till his coming, we imagine there wilbe no-
thing by them attempted, against us, and for
us, wee are not readie to doe any thing of mo-
ment.
And thus I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage Ja
n
25 95.
Heere are
fol.18v
XVII. 88
Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r Ja
n
25 95
Heere are some of opinion, upon l
res
out of Gelderland
at S
r
Francis Vere is either gone, or going about
some peece of service: w
ch
I am very certaine, if
e
Post come to him, before his departure, he will give
over: if not, for
at I ghesse, it is onely some ex-
ploit of surprise, or to beat some convoy of
e Enemie,
it wilbe quickly perfourmed./.
